definitions: sturdy table or surface designed for manual work like carpentry or repairs
examples: The carpenter organized his tools on the workbench before starting
She built the model airplane at her father's old workbench

definitions: book containing exercises and problems for students to practice skills
examples: Students completed math problems in their workbooks during class
The language workbook included grammar exercises and vocabulary drills

definitions: period of time during which work is performed, typically eight hours
examples: Her typical workday begins at nine and ends at five
The construction crew extended their workday to finish the project

definitions: organized sequence of steps or processes through which work progresses from start to finish
examples: The new software improved our document approval workflow significantly
Marketing redesigned their workflow to eliminate unnecessary bottlenecks

definitions: all people engaged in or available for work in a company or country
examples: The company expanded its workforce by hiring fifty new employees
Automation has changed the skills needed in today's workforce

definitions: person who works steadily and dependably at difficult tasks
machine or vehicle that performs reliably under heavy use
examples: Sarah has been the workhorse of our department for years
The accounting team treats Jim like their workhorse every tax season
This old truck has been our workhorse for twenty years
The printer became the office workhorse during report season

definitions: institution where poor people were housed and required to work in exchange for food and shelter
examples: Victorian England's workhouses were notorious for their harsh conditions
The old workhouse building has been converted into apartments

definitions: total amount of work assigned to or expected from a person or machine
examples: Teachers complained about their increasing workload each semester
The server crashed due to an unexpectedly heavy workload

definitions: man who does physical or manual labor, especially in construction or maintenance
examples: The workman arrived early to repair the broken window
Several workmen were renovating the old Victorian house

definitions: skill and quality evident in something made by hand or the work performed
examples: The furniture displayed excellent workmanship in every carved detail
Poor workmanship caused the deck to collapse after one winter

definitions: physical area or environment where someone works, including desk, tools, and equipment
examples: She organized her workspace to maximize productivity and comfort
The open office design created shared workspaces for collaboration

definitions: desk or area equipped with tools and equipment for a specific job
high-performance computer designed for technical or scientific applications
examples: Each employee was assigned a workstation with dual monitors
The ergonomic workstation helped reduce her back pain
The graphics designer needed a powerful workstation for rendering
Engineering workstations can cost thousands of dollars

definitions: elongated soft-bodied invertebrate animal without limbs that lives in soil
malicious computer program that replicates itself to spread to other computers
examples: Earthworms help aerate the soil in the garden
The robin pulled a worm from the wet grass
The computer worm infected thousands of systems overnight
IT security blocked the email worm before it spread

definitions: hypothetical tunnel through space-time that could create shortcuts for long journeys across the universe
examples: Scientists debate whether wormholes could actually exist in reality
The science fiction movie featured travel through a wormhole

definitions: act or state of feeling anxious and troubled about actual or potential problems
examples: Constant worrying about the future affected her sleep patterns
His worrying increased as the deadline approached

definitions: more unfavorable, unsatisfactory, or unpleasant condition compared to another
examples: The weather got worse as the storm approached
His condition was worse than the doctors initially thought

definitions: process of becoming progressively worse or more severe over time
examples: The worsening of air quality prompted health warnings
Economic indicators showed a worsening of market conditions

definitions: acts of religious devotion and reverence shown toward a deity or sacred object
examples: Sunday worship services begin at ten o'clock sharp
Different cultures have unique forms of worship and prayer

definitions: person who shows reverence and adoration for a deity through religious practices
examples: Worshippers filled the temple during the religious festival
The early morning worshipper prayed quietly in the chapel

definitions: most unfavorable, difficult, or unpleasant situation or quality in a range of possibilities
examples: This was the worst storm the region had seen in decades
She prepared for the worst possible outcome

definitions: people who have been injured, especially in warfare or accidents
examples: Medics rushed to help the wounded after the explosion
The hospital treated dozens of wounded from the crash

definitions: action or process of inflicting physical injury or emotional harm on someone
examples: The wounding of civilians violated international law
Her wounding remarks left him deeply hurt

definitions: exclamation expressing astonishment, admiration, or impressive surprise
examples: The audience let out a collective wow at the magic trick
Her performance earned wows from all the judges

definitions: ghost or spectral appearance of a person, especially one seen shortly before or after death
examples: A wraith appeared in the fog near the cemetery
The pale figure looked like a wraith in the moonlight

definitions: person who handles and takes care of horses or cattle on a ranch
person who engages in lengthy disputes or arguments
examples: The wrangler rounded up the horses at dawn
An experienced wrangler led tourists on the trail ride
The chief wrangler negotiated between the feuding departments
She became known as the office wrangler for difficult clients

definitions: engagement in complicated or prolonged disputes and arguments
activity of herding, handling, or managing livestock
examples: Political wrangling delayed the bill for months
Their constant wrangling disrupted the entire meeting
Cattle wrangling requires skill and patience
He spent summers wrangling horses on his uncle's ranch

definitions: design or feature that curves or extends around something to enclose or surround it
examples: The house featured a beautiful wraparound porch
She wore stylish wraparound sunglasses to the beach

definitions: piece of paper, plastic, or foil covering something to protect or contain it
examples: She carefully removed the candy wrapper and threw it away
The sandwich came in a biodegradable wrapper

definitions: material used to cover or protect something, especially gifts
action of covering something with paper, cloth, or other material
examples: The gift wrapping featured a festive holiday pattern
She saved the beautiful wrapping paper for reuse
The wrapping of presents took hours on Christmas Eve
Careful wrapping protected the fragile items during shipping

definitions: extreme anger or rage, often with a desire for vengeance or punishment
examples: The king's wrath fell upon those who betrayed him
She faced her mother's wrath after breaking the vase

definitions: circular arrangement of flowers, leaves, or other material used as decoration or honor
examples: A holiday wreath hung on the front door
They placed a memorial wreath at the grave site

definitions: badly damaged or destroyed remains of something, especially a vehicle
accident or incident that causes severe damage or destruction
examples: Divers explored the ancient shipwreck on the ocean floor
The car wreck blocked traffic for hours
The train wreck resulted from a signal failure
The storm caused several wrecks on the highway

definitions: broken remains or debris from something that has been badly damaged or destroyed
examples: Investigators searched through the wreckage for survivors
The tornado left wreckage scattered across the neighborhood

definitions: person or machine that demolishes buildings or structures
vehicle designed to tow away damaged or illegally parked vehicles
examples: The wrecker demolished the condemned building in hours
A professional wrecker carefully dismantled the old bridge
The wrecker arrived to tow the broken-down car
Police called a wrecker to remove the abandoned vehicle

definitions: action of demolishing or severely damaging buildings, vehicles, or other structures
examples: The wrecking of the old stadium began at dawn
Wrecking crews worked through the night clearing debris

definitions: small brown songbird with a short upright tail and loud melodious song
examples: A wren built its nest in the garden shed
The tiny wren sang loudly from the hedge

definitions: tool with jaws for gripping and turning nuts, bolts, or pipes
sudden violent twist or pull causing pain or damage
examples: The mechanic selected the right size wrench for the job
She kept a wrench in her car's emergency kit
He felt a painful wrench in his shoulder during the game
The emotional wrench of leaving home was difficult

definitions: physical contest or sport where opponents grapple and try to throw or pin each other
examples: The championship wrestle lasted for thirty intense minutes
Their friendly wrestle on the lawn ended in laughter

definitions: person who participates in wrestling as a sport or professional entertainment
examples: The wrestler trained six hours daily for the Olympics
Professional wrestlers combine athletics with theatrical performance

definitions: sport involving grappling techniques where opponents try to gain physical advantage
examples: High school wrestling requires strength and strategic thinking
Professional wrestling combines athletics with entertainment

definitions: unfortunate or unhappy person deserving pity or contempt
examples: The poor wretch had lost everything in the fire
He felt like a wretch after betraying his friend

definitions: worker skilled in manufacturing or constructing things, especially with wood
examples: The shipwright carefully shaped each timber for the vessel
A wheelwright repaired the wagon's broken wheel

definitions: line or fold in skin caused by aging or facial expressions
small line or fold in fabric or paper
examples: Laugh lines created wrinkles around her eyes
The dermatologist recommended cream for reducing wrinkles
She ironed every wrinkle from her interview outfit
The paper had a wrinkle from being folded

definitions: small timepiece worn on a strap or band around the wrist
examples: His vintage wristwatch was a family heirloom
She checked her wristwatch and hurried to the meeting

definitions: formal written order issued by a court or judicial authority commanding specific action
examples: The court issued a writ demanding his appearance
Lawyers filed a writ of habeas corpus

definitions: illegal, dishonest, or morally wrong behavior or activity that violates laws or ethical standards
examples: The investigation uncovered years of corporate wrongdoing
She refused to participate in any wrongdoing at work

definitions: building providing temporary accommodation, often in rural or recreational areas
local branch or meeting place of a fraternal organization
examples: The ski lodge offered warm beds after cold days on slopes
They stayed at a hunting lodge deep in the forest
He attended the Masonic lodge meeting every Thursday evening
The lodge voted to admit new members
